_comment: Created by EFisher on 26/03/2014 16:40:17 using v2.1
title: Are there differences between staff groups in reporting working extra hours?
analysis_commentary:
The extent to which different staff report working extra hours varies quite dramatically between the groups.

Of the staff groups we've investigated, three clinical staff groups (medical/dental, registered nurses and health visitors), report working extra hours more than the national average. However, this was not as great a difference when looking at general managers; across the years, 20% more staff in this group reported working extra hours when compared to national results.

There was also variation in staff reporting working extra hours based on staff characteristics. A higher percentage of male staff reported working extra hours than females, this ranged between 4% and 7% greater than what is reported nationally in each year (data not shown). Also there was a consistent difference in how many staff report working extra hours based on staff age. Less 16 to 30 year olds (on average across all years 3% less) and more 41 to 50 year olds (on average across all years 5% more) report working extra hours compared to the national average (data not shown).
data_source: Department of Health, Survey of NHS Staff
